metadata.title: Intermediate Week 1 — Accumulation Phase Launch (PPL Split Introduction)
metadata.progressionFocus: Establish baseline volume (12-14 sets per muscle group), RPE 7-8

microcycleOutput.overview: Week 1 — Accumulation Phase Launch. Welcome to your first week of intermediate PPL training. You're transitioning from 3-4 days/week to 6 days/week, which means higher frequency per muscle group (2x/week) but distributed across more sessions. This week establishes your baseline volume: 12-14 sets per muscle group at moderate intensity (RPE 7-8, ~70-75% 1RM). The focus is on learning the PPL split structure and movement selection while leaving 2-3 reps in reserve (RIR) on all sets. You should finish each workout feeling challenged but not destroyed—accumulation is about building volume tolerance over 6 weeks, not maxing out in Week 1. Track all your lifts (weight, reps, RPE) in a training log. This data will guide your progression through Weeks 2-6. Expect mild fatigue as your body adapts to the increased frequency, but soreness should be manageable (you're not a beginner anymore). Rest 90-120sec between compound sets, 60-90sec between accessories/isolation.
days: Day 1 (Monday) — Push: Chest & Shoulders Emphasis. Primary focus: Horizontal and vertical pressing with chest/front delt priority. Volume: 12-14 sets for chest, 10-12 for shoulders, 6-8 for triceps. Compounds first (3-4 sets of 6-10 reps, RPE 7-8), accessories next (3-4 sets of 10-15 reps, RPE 8), isolation last (2-3 sets of 12-20 reps, RPE 9). Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min: light cardio + dynamic stretches (arm circles, band pull-aparts, scapular push-ups), (2) Barbell Bench Press 4x8 @ RPE 7-8 (your main pressing strength movement—start conservatively, maybe 70-75% estimated 1RM. Rest 120sec), (3) Incline Dumbbell Press 3x10-12 @ RPE 7-8 (upper chest focus, control the descent), (4) Machine Chest Press OR Dips 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (machine allows pushing without stability demands; dips are advanced—use assistance if needed. Rest 90sec), (5) Dumbbell Shoulder Press 3x10 @ RPE 7-8 (front delt emphasis, strict form, no leg drive), (6) Lateral Raises 3x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (side delts, lighter weight, control the descent, don't swing), (7) Overhead Triceps Extension OR Skull Crushers 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (triceps are pre-fatigued from pressing, so this is accessory volume), (8) Cooldown 5min: stretching (chest, shoulders, triceps). Record all weights and reps—you'll use this to track progression through Weeks 2-6.

Day 2 (Tuesday) — Pull: Back & Biceps. Primary focus: Vertical and horizontal pulling with back width/thickness balance. Volume: 14-16 sets for back, 8-10 for biceps. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min: light cardio + band pull-aparts, scapular retractions, (2) Conventional Deadlift 4x6 @ RPE 7-8 (main posterior chain movement, focus on form and speed—don't grind reps. Rest 2-3min), (3) Pull-ups OR Lat Pulldown 4x8-10 @ RPE 7-8 (back width, focus on pulling elbows down, not hands. If doing pull-ups, use assistance if needed to hit 8-10 reps. Rest 90sec), (4) Barbell Row OR Chest-Supported Row 3x10-12 @ RPE 7-8 (back thickness, pull to sternum, squeeze shoulder blades together), (5) Single-Arm Dumbbell Row 3x12/arm @ RPE 8 (unilateral work for balance and stretch), (6) Face Pulls 3x15-20 @ RPE 8 (rear delts and upper back health, control the contraction), (7) Barbell Curls 3x10-12 @ RPE 8 (biceps mass builder, strict form, no swinging), (8) Hammer Curls 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (brachialis and forearm, complements barbell curls), (9) Cooldown 5min: stretching (lats, biceps, forearms).

Day 3 (Wednesday) — Legs: Quad Emphasis. Primary focus: Knee-dominant movements (squats, leg press, extensions). Volume: 14-16 sets for quads, 6-8 for hamstrings/glutes, 4-6 for calves. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min: light cardio + leg swings, bodyweight squats, ankle mobility, (2) Barbell Back Squat 4x8 @ RPE 7-8 (main quad/leg developer, focus on depth and tempo—3sec descent, 1sec pause, explosive up. Rest 2-3min), (3) Leg Press 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (high volume quad work, push through heels, full ROM), (4) Bulgarian Split Squat 3x10/leg @ RPE 7-8 (unilateral quad/glute work, control the descent, front leg does the work), (5) Leg Extensions 3x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (quad isolation, control the eccentric, squeeze at top), (6) Romanian Deadlift 3x12 @ RPE 7-8 (hamstring stretch and load, lighter than conventional DL—focus on eccentric), (7) Leg Curls 3x15 @ RPE 8 (hamstring isolation, complements RDL), (8) Calf Raises 4x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (standing or seated, full stretch at bottom, full contraction at top), (9) Cooldown 5min: quad/hamstring stretching, foam rolling if needed.

Day 4 (Thursday) — Push: Triceps & Front Delts. Primary focus: Second push day with variation in exercise selection, more triceps volume. Volume: 10-12 sets for chest, 8-10 for shoulders, 8-10 for triceps. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Incline Barbell Press 4x8-10 @ RPE 7-8 (upper chest emphasis, different angle than Monday's flat bench), (3) Flat Dumbbell Press 3x10-12 @ RPE 7-8 (chest thickness, squeeze at top), (4) Cable Flyes OR Pec Deck 3x12-15 @ RPE 8-9 (chest isolation, stretch at bottom, squeeze at contraction), (5) Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press 3x10-12 @ RPE 7-8 (front/side delt, similar to Monday but more reps for volume), (6) Front Raises 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (front delt isolation, alternating or both arms), (7) Close-Grip Bench Press 3x10-12 @ RPE 7-8 (triceps mass builder, elbows tucked), (8) Triceps Pushdowns 3x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (triceps isolation, keep elbows stationary, full extension), (9) Cooldown 5min. Track weights—compare to Monday to see if fatigue is accumulating.

Day 5 (Friday) — Pull: Rear Delts & Biceps. Primary focus: Second pull day with rear delt emphasis and higher biceps volume. Volume: 12-14 sets for back, 10-12 for biceps, 6-8 for rear delts. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Weighted Pull-ups OR Lat Pulldown 4x8-10 @ RPE 7-8 (back width, if you did pull-ups Tuesday, do pulldowns today for variation), (3) T-Bar Row OR Pendlay Row 3x10-12 @ RPE 7-8 (back thickness, explosive pull, controlled descent), (4) Seated Cable Row 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (mid-back, squeeze at contraction, feel the stretch), (5) Straight-Arm Pulldown 3x15 @ RPE 8 (lat isolation, keep arms straight, pull with lats not arms), (6) Reverse Pec Deck OR Rear Delt Flyes 4x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (rear delt priority, high volume, control the movement), (7) Incline Dumbbell Curls 3x12 @ RPE 8 (biceps stretch at bottom, squeeze at top), (8) Cable Curls 3x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (biceps pump, constant tension), (9) Cooldown 5min.

Day 6 (Saturday) — Legs: Hamstring & Glute Emphasis. Primary focus: Hip-dominant movements (RDLs, hip thrusts, leg curls). Volume: 8-10 sets for hamstrings, 8-10 for glutes, 6-8 for quads, 4-6 for calves. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min: hip mobility, glute activation (banded walks, glute bridges), (2) Romanian Deadlift 4x10 @ RPE 7-8 (main hamstring/glute builder, feel the stretch, control the descent. Rest 2min), (3) Hip Thrusts 4x12-15 @ RPE 8 (glute isolation, squeeze at top, full ROM, can use barbell or Smith machine), (4) Lying Leg Curls 3x12-15 @ RPE 8 (hamstring isolation, control the eccentric, squeeze at contraction), (5) Walking Lunges 3x12/leg @ RPE 7-8 (quad/glute/stability, bodyweight or light dumbbells), (6) Leg Press (Narrow Stance) 3x15 @ RPE 8 (quad involvement but glute emphasis with narrow stance), (7) Seated Calf Raises 4x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (soleus emphasis, full ROM), (8) Cooldown 5min. This completes your first 6-day PPL cycle! Sunday is full rest.

Day 7 (Sunday) — Rest (or optional Zone 2 cardio). Complete rest is recommended after 6 consecutive training days. If you feel restless, you can do 20-30min easy cardio (bike, incline walk, rowing) at conversational pace—this aids recovery without adding stress. Otherwise, prioritize sleep, nutrition (hit protein targets: ~1g/lb bodyweight for hypertrophy), and mental recovery. Reflect on Week 1: How did the 6-day split feel? Any exercises that felt awkward? Any movements where you felt unusually strong or weak? Note these observations—they'll guide your training adjustments. Week 2 will follow the same structure but with slightly higher loads (add 5-10lbs to compounds if Week 1 felt easy). Accumulation phase continues through Week 6, gradually increasing volume (adding 1-2 sets every 2 weeks). Your body is adapting to higher frequency—trust the process.

metadata.title: Intermediate Week 7 — Deload Week (Recovery & Fatigue Dissipation)
metadata.progressionFocus: Reduce volume by 50%, maintain exercises, dissipate accumulated fatigue

microcycleOutput.overview: Week 7 — Deload (Recovery Week). After 6 weeks of progressive volume accumulation, your body has accumulated fatigue—both muscular and neural. This week is a scheduled deload: you'll reduce volume by 50% (cut sets in half), reduce load to 70-80% of your working weights from Week 6, and keep intensity moderate (RPE 6-7, no grinding reps). The goal is NOT to coast or skip the gym—deloads are ACTIVE recovery. You'll maintain the same exercise selection and training frequency (still 6 days), but the reduced stress allows your body to dissipate fatigue, repair accumulated microtrauma, and super-compensate (adapt positively). Expect to feel fresh and energized by the end of Week 7. Sleep and nutrition remain critical—don't cut calories just because volume is lower. This deload prepares you for the intensification phase (Weeks 9-14), where loads will increase significantly. Many lifters see PRs immediately after a deload because they're fully recovered. Embrace the lighter week—it's part of the plan, not a break.
days: Day 1 (Monday) — Push: Chest & Shoulders (DELOAD). Volume: Cut all sets in half (e.g., if you did 4 sets of bench, do 2 sets today). Load: Use 70-80% of Week 6 working weights. Reps: Stay in the same rep ranges. RPE: 6-7 (leave 3-4 reps in reserve, no strain). Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min (still important—prepare joints and CNS), (2) Barbell Bench Press 2x8 @ RPE 6-7 (if you used 185lbs in Week 6, use ~135-150lbs today—light and crisp), (3) Incline Dumbbell Press 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7 (control the movement, no grinding), (4) Machine Chest Press OR Dips 2x12-15 @ RPE 6-7 (should feel easy—that's the point), (5) Dumbbell Shoulder Press 2x10 @ RPE 6-7, (6) Lateral Raises 2x15-20 @ RPE 7 (lighter weight, perfect form), (7) Overhead Triceps Extension 2x12-15 @ RPE 6-7, (8) Cooldown 5min. Total session time should be ~40-50min instead of 60-75min. You should leave the gym feeling refreshed, not depleted.

Day 2 (Tuesday) — Pull: Back & Biceps (DELOAD). Same deload principles: half the sets, lighter loads, moderate intensity. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Conventional Deadlift 2x6 @ RPE 6-7 (significantly lighter than Week 6—focus on speed and form, not load. This is technique practice), (3) Pull-ups OR Lat Pulldown 2x8-10 @ RPE 6-7 (should feel smooth and controlled), (4) Barbell Row OR Chest-Supported Row 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7, (5) Single-Arm Dumbbell Row 2x12/arm @ RPE 7, (6) Face Pulls 2x15-20 @ RPE 7 (rear delt health—still important during deload), (7) Barbell Curls 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7 (light weight, strict form), (8) Hammer Curls 2x12-15 @ RPE 7, (9) Cooldown 5min. Notice how much easier recovery is with reduced volume—you should feel minimal soreness tomorrow.

Day 3 (Wednesday) — Legs: Quad Emphasis (DELOAD). Same deload approach. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Barbell Back Squat 2x8 @ RPE 6-7 (if you squatted 225lbs in Week 6, use ~165-185lbs today—focus on depth and tempo, not weight), (3) Leg Press 2x12-15 @ RPE 7 (moderate load, full ROM), (4) Bulgarian Split Squat 2x10/leg @ RPE 6-7 (unilateral work with lighter load), (5) Leg Extensions 2x15-20 @ RPE 7 (pump work, not grinding), (6) Romanian Deadlift 2x12 @ RPE 6-7, (7) Leg Curls 2x15 @ RPE 7, (8) Calf Raises 2x15-20 @ RPE 7, (9) Cooldown 5min. Legs should feel fresh—no heavy soreness or joint stress.

Day 4 (Thursday) — Push: Triceps & Front Delts (DELOAD). Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Incline Barbell Press 2x8-10 @ RPE 6-7, (3) Flat Dumbbell Press 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7, (4) Cable Flyes 2x12-15 @ RPE 7, (5) Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7, (6) Front Raises 2x12-15 @ RPE 7, (7) Close-Grip Bench Press 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7, (8) Triceps Pushdowns 2x15-20 @ RPE 7, (9) Cooldown 5min. This is the second push day of the deload week—you should feel strong and controlled, not fatigued.

Day 5 (Friday) — Pull: Rear Delts & Biceps (DELOAD). Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Weighted Pull-ups OR Lat Pulldown 2x8-10 @ RPE 6-7 (focus on quality reps), (3) T-Bar Row OR Pendlay Row 2x10-12 @ RPE 6-7, (4) Seated Cable Row 2x12-15 @ RPE 7, (5) Straight-Arm Pulldown 2x15 @ RPE 7, (6) Reverse Pec Deck OR Rear Delt Flyes 2x15-20 @ RPE 7, (7) Incline Dumbbell Curls 2x12 @ RPE 7, (8) Cable Curls 2x15-20 @ RPE 7, (9) Cooldown 5min.

Day 6 (Saturday) — Legs: Hamstring & Glute Emphasis (DELOAD). Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Romanian Deadlift 2x10 @ RPE 6-7 (lighter load, focus on hamstring stretch and control), (3) Hip Thrusts 2x12-15 @ RPE 7 (glute activation, not maximal load), (4) Lying Leg Curls 2x12-15 @ RPE 7, (5) Walking Lunges 2x12/leg @ RPE 6-7, (6) Leg Press (Narrow Stance) 2x15 @ RPE 7, (7) Seated Calf Raises 2x15-20 @ RPE 7, (8) Cooldown 5min. This completes your deload week. You should feel significantly fresher than you did at the end of Week 6.

Day 7 (Sunday) — Rest (or optional VERY light activity). Full rest is ideal. If you want movement, keep it to 15-20min easy walk or gentle yoga—no Zone 2 cardio this week (even that adds stress). Focus on sleep (aim for 8-9 hours), hydration, and nutrition. Reflect on the deload: Did you feel guilty for lifting lighter? That's normal but misguided—deloads are when adaptation happens. Your muscles, tendons, joints, and nervous system have been repairing all week. Week 8 continues the deload (same structure), then Week 9 begins intensification phase (higher loads, advanced techniques, same volume). You're setting yourself up for a massive performance jump in the coming weeks. Trust the process.

metadata.title: Intermediate Week 13 — Peak Intensification (Advanced Techniques & Max Hypertrophy)
metadata.progressionFocus: High load (RPE 8-9), advanced techniques (rest-pause, drop sets, slow eccentrics), maintain volume

microcycleOutput.overview: Week 13 — Peak Intensification (Advanced Techniques). You're in the final push of the intensification phase (Week 13 of 14 before final deload). Your body is fully recovered from the Week 7-8 deload and has adapted to higher loads over the past 4 weeks. This week, intensity peaks: RPE 8-9 (~80-85% 1RM) on compounds, with only 1-2 reps left in reserve. Volume remains at 14-16 sets per muscle group (same as accumulation phase), but now you're incorporating advanced techniques to maximize hypertrophy stimulus: rest-pause sets (take a 15-20sec pause mid-set, then continue), drop sets (reduce weight 20-30% and continue to failure), and slow eccentrics (4-5sec negative on final sets). These techniques create mechanical tension, metabolic stress, and muscle damage—the three drivers of hypertrophy. Expect significant muscle soreness and fatigue accumulation. Sleep becomes non-negotiable (8-9 hours minimum), and nutrition must support recovery (slight calorie surplus, 1g+ protein per lb bodyweight). This is the hardest week of the program—your lifts should feel heavy, your muscles should burn, and you should be counting down to Week 15's final deload. But this is where growth happens. Push intelligently, not recklessly. Form is still king—advanced techniques amplify stimulus but also amplify injury risk if done sloppily.
days: Day 1 (Monday) — Push: Chest & Shoulders (INTENSIFICATION). Volume: 12-14 sets for chest, 10-12 for shoulders, 8-10 for triceps. Intensity: RPE 8-9 on all compounds and most accessories. Advanced techniques deployed today: rest-pause on final set of bench press, slow eccentrics (4-5sec) on incline press final set, drop set on lateral raises. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min + activation (band work, light pressing), (2) Barbell Bench Press 4x6-8 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy weight—if you can do 9 reps, weight is too light. On final set, hit 6 reps, rack the bar, rest 15-20sec, then squeeze out 2-3 more reps—this is REST-PAUSE. Rest 2-3min between sets), (3) Incline Dumbbell Press 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (on final set, use 4-5sec eccentric on every rep—this increases time under tension. You may need to drop reps to 6-8 due to fatigue. Rest 2min), (4) Machine Chest Press 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (strict form, squeeze at contraction, no rest-pause—just straight sets taken close to failure), (5) Dumbbell Shoulder Press 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy, controlled, no leg drive—pure shoulder strength), (6) Lateral Raises 3x12-15 @ RPE 9 (on final set, after hitting failure at 12-15 reps, drop weight by 30-40% and immediately continue for another 8-10 reps—DROP SET for metabolic stress. Expect intense burn), (7) Overhead Triceps Extension 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (triceps are pre-fatigued from pressing—even moderate weight will feel heavy), (8) Cooldown 5-10min: stretching + light foam rolling (chest, shoulders, triceps). Total session: 70-80min. You should feel thoroughly worked.

Day 2 (Tuesday) — Pull: Back & Biceps (INTENSIFICATION). Advanced techniques today: rest-pause on deadlift final set, slow eccentrics on pull-ups/pulldowns, drop set on bicep curls. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min + activation (band pull-aparts, scapular work), (2) Conventional Deadlift 4x5-6 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy deadlifts—on final set, hit 5 reps, rest 20-30sec, then grind out 1-2 more reps. Form is CRITICAL here—don't round your back chasing reps. Rest 3min between sets), (3) Weighted Pull-ups OR Lat Pulldown 4x6-8 @ RPE 8-9 (on final set, add 4-5sec eccentric on every rep—control the descent, feel the lat stretch. This is brutal but effective. Rest 2min), (4) Barbell Row 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (explosive concentric, controlled eccentric, squeeze at top), (5) Single-Arm Dumbbell Row 3x10/arm @ RPE 8-9 (unilateral work allows full ROM and stretch—go heavy), (6) Face Pulls 3x15-20 @ RPE 8-9 (rear delt health and hypertrophy—don't skip this), (7) Barbell Curls 3x8-10 @ RPE 9 (heavy, strict form—no swinging. On final set, after hitting 8-10 reps, drop weight 30% and pump out another 8-10 reps—DROP SET), (8) Hammer Curls 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (brachialis work, complements barbell curls), (9) Cooldown 5-10min. Back should feel pumped and fatigued.

Day 3 (Wednesday) — Legs: Quad Emphasis (INTENSIFICATION). Advanced techniques: rest-pause on squats, slow eccentrics on Bulgarian split squats, drop set on leg extensions. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min + mobility and activation, (2) Barbell Back Squat 4x6-8 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy squats—on final set, hit 6 reps, rack the bar, rest 20sec, then squeeze 2-3 more reps. This is neurally demanding—stay focused. Rest 3min between sets), (3) Leg Press 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy load, full ROM, control the descent—don't bounce at bottom), (4) Bulgarian Split Squat 3x8/leg @ RPE 8-9 (on final set, add 4-5sec eccentric on every rep—this will light up your quads. You may need assistance for balance. Rest 90sec), (5) Leg Extensions 3x12-15 @ RPE 9 (on final set, after hitting failure at 12-15, drop weight 40% and immediately rep out another 10-12—DROP SET for quad pump. Expect significant burn), (6) Romanian Deadlift 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (hamstring stretch and load—control the eccentric, feel the tension), (7) Leg Curls 3x12-15 @ RPE 8-9 (hamstring isolation, squeeze at contraction), (8) Calf Raises 4x12-15 @ RPE 9 (heavy weight, full ROM—calves respond to high intensity), (9) Cooldown 5-10min. Legs should feel torched—expect significant DOMS tomorrow.

Day 4 (Thursday) — Push: Triceps & Front Delts (INTENSIFICATION). Second push day with advanced techniques. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Incline Barbell Press 4x6-8 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy incline work—on final set, rest-pause: 6 reps, 15sec rest, 2-3 more reps. Rest 2-3min), (3) Flat Dumbbell Press 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (on final set, slow eccentric 4-5sec on every rep), (4) Cable Flyes 3x10-12 @ RPE 9 (chest isolation, stretch at bottom, squeeze at contraction—no advanced techniques here, just straight sets close to failure), (5) Seated Dumbbell Shoulder Press 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (strict form, heavy load), (6) Front Raises 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (front delt isolation), (7) Close-Grip Bench Press 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (triceps mass builder—heavy, elbows tucked), (8) Triceps Pushdowns 3x12-15 @ RPE 9 (on final set, drop set: hit failure, reduce weight 30%, continue for 10-12 more reps), (9) Cooldown 5-10min.

Day 5 (Friday) — Pull: Rear Delts & Biceps (INTENSIFICATION). Second pull day with peak intensity. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Weighted Pull-ups OR Lat Pulldown 4x6-8 @ RPE 8-9 (if doing pull-ups, add weight; if pulldown, go heavy. On final set, rest-pause: 6 reps, 20sec rest, 2-3 more), (3) T-Bar Row OR Pendlay Row 3x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (explosive pull, controlled descent, squeeze at top), (4) Seated Cable Row 3x10-12 @ RPE 8-9 (on final set, slow eccentric 4-5sec every rep), (5) Straight-Arm Pulldown 3x12-15 @ RPE 8-9 (lat isolation, keep arms straight), (6) Reverse Pec Deck OR Rear Delt Flyes 4x12-15 @ RPE 9 (rear delt priority—on final set, drop set: failure, reduce weight 30%, continue 10-12 reps), (7) Incline Dumbbell Curls 3x10-12 @ RPE 9 (stretch at bottom, squeeze at top—on final set, slow eccentric 4-5sec), (8) Cable Curls 3x12-15 @ RPE 9 (biceps pump, constant tension—no advanced techniques, just straight failure sets), (9) Cooldown 5-10min.

Day 6 (Saturday) — Legs: Hamstring & Glute Emphasis (INTENSIFICATION). Final training day of the week—bring intensity. Session: (1) Warm-up 5-10min, (2) Romanian Deadlift 4x8-10 @ RPE 8-9 (heavy RDLs—on final set, rest-pause: 8 reps, 20sec rest, 2-3 more. Rest 2-3min between sets), (3) Hip Thrusts 4x10-12 @ RPE 9 (heavy barbell, squeeze glutes hard at top—on final set, add 4-5sec eccentric every rep), (4) Lying Leg Curls 3x10-12 @ RPE 9 (on final set, drop set: failure, reduce 30%, continue 10 reps), (5) Walking Lunges 3x10/leg @ RPE 8-9 (quad/glute work, control the descent), (6) Leg Press (Narrow Stance) 3x12-15 @ RPE 8-9 (glute emphasis), (7) Seated Calf Raises 4x12-15 @ RPE 9 (soleus work, full ROM, squeeze at top), (8) Cooldown 5-10min. This completes Week 13—you've pushed hard all week with advanced techniques.

Day 7 (Sunday) — Rest (NO cardio). Full rest. Your body has been under significant stress all week (advanced techniques create more damage than standard sets). Sleep 8-9 hours minimum. Eat at maintenance or slight surplus—don't diet during intensification. Hydrate well. If you're extremely sore, do 10-15min of VERY light walking or gentle stretching, but otherwise prioritize complete rest. Reflect on Week 13: How did the advanced techniques feel? Did you maintain form during rest-pause/drop sets? Any exercises where you felt particularly strong or weak? Week 14 is the final intensification week (same structure, potentially even heavier loads if you feel recovered). Then Weeks 15-16 are final deload and assessment. You're in the home stretch—one more week of peak intensity, then recovery and results. Your body is adapting to massive stimulus. Trust the process, eat, sleep, and prepare for Week 14.
